question.title: Google Drive API doesn't play well with ProGuard (NPE)

node.contents: Currently, I'm having experience that, a piece of code, which makes use of Google Drive API is running fine without introducing ProGuard.

astNode.text: Currently, I'm having experience that, a piece of code, which makes use of Google Drive API is running fine without introducing ProGuard.

node.contents: However, after introducing ProGuard, I'm getting the following run-time error.

astNode.text: However, after introducing ProGuard, I'm getting the following run-time error.

elements.contents:
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:856)
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException

node.contents: In my proguard, I thought having the following 2 key instructions, able to prevent the crash from happen : I tell ProGuard never touch on jackson and Google libraries.

node.contents: Note that, I had another try is that, I thought obfuscate process causes NPE happens. Hence, I try to disable it using -dontobfuscate. But this time, I will not able to generate APK file, and getting a popular error message : Conversion to Dalvik format failed with error 1

node.contents: Here is the proguard configuration which causes NPE at Google Drive API.

astNode.text: Here is the proguard configuration which causes NPE at Google Drive API.

fragments.text:
-optimizationpasses 1
-dontusemixedcaseclassnames
-dontskipnonpubliclibraryclasses
-dontpreverify
-verbose
-optimizations !code/simplification/arithmetic,!field/*,!class/merging/*

# Comment out the following line, will cause popular "Conversion to Dalvik format failed with error 1"
##-dontobfuscate

-dontwarn

-dontwarn javax.swing.**
-dontwarn java.awt.**
-dontwarn org.jasypt.encryption.pbe.**
-dontwarn java.beans.**
-dontwarn org.joda.time.**
-dontwarn com.google.android.gms.**
-dontwarn org.w3c.dom.bootstrap.**
-dontwarn com.ibm.icu.text.**
-dontwarn demo.**

# Hold onto the mapping.text file, it can be used to unobfuscate stack traces in the developer console using the retrace tool
-printmapping mapping.txt

# Keep line numbers so they appear in the stack trace of the develeper console 
-keepattributes *Annotation*,

node.contents: I suspect Types.getSuperParameterizedType returning null. So, I further look into Types.getSuperParameterizedType.

node.contents: What is the possible root cause that may cause getSuperParameterizedType returning null, after processed by ProGuard?

astNode.text: What is the possible root cause that may cause getSuperParameterizedType returning null, after processed by ProGuard?

node.contents: I don't know Google prepares proguard configuration for their libraries. Gonna to try them out.

astNode.text: I don't know Google prepares proguard configuration for their libraries. Gonna to try them out.

node.contents: This is working for me

astNode.text: This is working for me

node.contents: Proper combination is :

astNode.text: Proper combination is :

node.contents: -keepattributes Signature,RuntimeVisibleAnnotations,AnnotationDefault

astNode.text: -keepattributes Signature,RuntimeVisibleAnnotations,AnnotationDefault

node.contents: There's proguard configuration prepared by Google for project google-api-java-client

astNode.text: There's proguard configuration prepared by Google for project google-api-java-client

node.contents: Maybe check bin/proguard/obfuscated.jar to see what getSuperParameterizedType() method really has for code afterward. You could visually inspect for comparison to the source above. Not a direct answer, but may be useful depending on the result. Maybe use [link](http://java.decompiler.free.fr) if you need a decompiler.

node.contents: First -keeping a class does not mean to not touch it. It means do not change its name, and use it as a basis for determining if other classes are not referenced & can be deleted.

astNode.text: First -keeping a class does not mean to not touch it. It means do not change its name, and use it as a basis for determining if other classes are not referenced & can be deleted.

node.contents: Optimization still occurs, which is likely your problem. Next step I would do is try with: -dontoptimize

astNode.text: Optimization still occurs, which is likely your problem. Next step I would do is try with: -dontoptimize

node.contents: This should cause your other optimizations to be ignored.

astNode.text: This should cause your other optimizations to be ignored.

node.contents: BTW, not sure what version of SDK you are using. Am using 15, 20 is latest, and a proguard-project.txt file is create with the project. The optimization options it uses is:

astNode.text: BTW, not sure what version of SDK you are using. Am using 15, 20 is latest, and a proguard-project.txt file is create with the project. The optimization options it uses is:

node.contents: If turning off optimization gets it running, maybe turning off all the optimizations (that's what ! does) the SDK does, will allow you to do optimization as well.

astNode.text: If turning off optimization gets it running, maybe turning off all the optimizations (that's what ! does) the SDK does, will allow you to do optimization as well.

node.contents: The method Types.getSuperParameterizedType relies on information about generics. Generics are erased in Java. The compiler only adds them as annotation attributes, the JVM ignores them, and ProGuard discards them unless you tell it not to. So this might help:

astNode.text: The method Types.getSuperParameterizedType relies on information about generics. Generics are erased in Java. The compiler only adds them as annotation attributes, the JVM ignores them, and ProGuard discards them unless you tell it not to. So this might help:
